questions.text: A 60 y/o male suddenly experiences an intense headache, described as the worst headache of his life, followed by vomiting and photophobia. O/E he has neck stiffness and a dilated pupil on the right side. A CT scan reveals bleeding in the subarachnoid space. Which of the following is the most common cause of this condition?
Which specific nerve is affected in Frey's syndrome?

A male patient comes with a gradually increasing enlargement for the past one and a half years. Upon examination, the swelling demonstrates inconsistency in texture and matches the appearance depicted in the provided image. What is the likely underlying reason for this?
Most common oral cancer is:

questions.text: Which of the following tests would a surgeon advise first in a patient with a large thyroid swelling?

A car driver was brought into the A & E following a RTA with complaints of breathlessness. On examination, his vitals are PR-112/min, BP-100/70, SpO2-90 %, and there is extensive bruising on his chest. What is the management of this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Internal operative fixation of the fracture’s segments

questions.explanation:
Flail chest

Definition
  • It occurs when three or more consecutive ribs are fractured in at least two places, creating a flail segment that moves independently.
  • It exhibits paradoxical chest movement (inwards during inhalation & outwards during exhalation)

Clinical features
  • Hypoventilation: Reduced lung ventilation leads to low oxygen and high CO₂ levels.
  • Mediastinal Flutter: Abnormal mediastinal movement risks sudden cardiac arrest.
  • Pendular Air Movement: Inefficient air exchange between lungs.

Complications
  • Hemothorax: Blood in the chest cavity.
  • Pneumothorax: Air in the chest cavity.

Management
  • Ventilation Support:
    • Oxygen supplementation and Analgesics- Initial management
    • IPPV is the preferred TOC.
    • Tracheostomy if support exceeds 10 days.
  • Injury Management:
    • Intercostal Tube Drainage: Removes air/fluids from the pleural space.
    • Rib Fixation: Stabilises the chest wall.
  • Supportive Care:
    • Blood Transfusions: For blood loss.
    • IV Fluids: For hydration.
    • Antibiotics: To prevent infection.
    • Medications: Bronchodilators and steroids.
  • Thoracotomy:
    • Considered in severe cases

questions.text: Which statement regarding retrosternal goitre is accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Operated in all patients regardless of symptoms

options.label: B
options.text: Sternal incision is always required to operate

options.label: C
options.text: It receives blood supply from the thoracodorsal artery

options.label: D
options.text: Most of the retrosternal goitres can be removed by a neck incision

questions.correct_answer: D. Most of the retrosternal goitres can be removed by a neck incision
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Most of the retrosternal goitres can be removed by a neck incision:

Retrosternal goitre

Definition
  • A thyroid gland enlargement that extends into the mediastinum behind the Sternum

Types
  • Primary: Ectopic thyroid tissue in the mediastinum (10%)
  • Secondary: Starts from neck and extends retrosternally (90%)

Clinical Features
  • Neck Swelling with Compression Symptoms: Difficulty breathing (tracheal compression) and swallowing (esophageal compression).
  • Pemberton Sign: Facial flushing and increased difficulty breathing when raising the arms due to thoracic inlet compression.

Diagnosis
  • Physical examination: Limited palpation of the lower border of the thyroid swelling.
  • Imaging: Computed Tomography (CT) Scan of the Neck and Chest is IOC to assess the extent of mediastinal involvement and to evaluate compression of surrounding structures.

Management
  • Primary / Recurrent / Large Malignant Retrosternal Goiter - Median Sternotomy (Option B ruled out)
  • Secondary Retrosternal Goiter - Cervical / Neck Incision

questions.text: What is the definition of the Miami criteria regarding intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) measurement among the options listed below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - H

questions.text: Which of the following structures is most likely to be injured, leading to lower lip paralysis in a 30-year-old teacher who underwent parotidectomy?

options.label: A
options.text: Temporal branch of the facial nerve

questions.correct_answer: D. Mandibular branch of facial nerve
questions.explanation:
Complications of Parotidectomy:

Complication

Description

Temporary Facial Palsy
  • Mostly the lower branches of the facial nerve - the marginal mandibular nerve.
  • Most patients recover over time.

Infection

  • Rare, as parotidectomy is a clean procedure.
  • Aseptic precautions and timely drain removal reduce the risk.

Hematoma Formation
  • Uncommon.
  • Careful intraoperative hemostasis can prevent it.
  • Larger hematomas may indicate a bleeding disorder and require management.

Sialocele Formation

  • Occurs if the main ductal system is exposed.
  • Preventable with subcapsular dissection.
  • Treatment: Anticholinergics, aspiration, and pressure dressings.

Retromandibular area hollowing
  • Can occur post-surgery
  • Reduced by placing autologous fat grafts during the surgery.

Frey’s Syndrome
  • Also known as gustatory sweating;
  • Caused by the cross-innervation of sweat glands by regenerating nerve fibres of the auriculotemporal nerve.
  • For mild cases: Give antiperspirants;
  • Severe cases: Botulinum toxin injections or tympanic neurectomy.

Permanent Facial Nerve Weakness
  • D/t transection of the facial nerve during the surgery.

Facial Numbness
  • Permanent numbness of the earlobe,
  • D/t transection of the great auricular nerve during the surgery.

questions.correct_answer: A. Type 3 branchial fistula has its internal orifice on cricopharynxgeus
questions.explanation: Correct answer A) Type 3 branchial fistula has its internal orifice on cricopharynxgeu

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient who is a chronic tobacco chewer presents with a whitish lesion on the gingivobuccal sulcus for 7 months. What is the next best step in the management of this condition?
questions.explanation:
It is a progressive condition involving deep fibrosis in the oral mucosa, characterized by fibrous bands and considered a precancerous lesion.

Cause
  • Hypersensitivity to tobacco, betel nut, chilli, areca nut, vitamin deficiencies, localised collagen disorders.
  • Leads to alteration of collagen metabolism causing juxtaepithelial progressive inflammatory fibrosis of the submucosa.
  • This leads to atrophy and dysplasia.

Clinical features

  • Common in Asians
  • Males and females are equally affected.
  • Soreness in the mouth more during meals
  • Burning, also more while eating
  • Vesicular eruptions
  • Trismus
  • Difficulty in protruding tongue
  • Fibrosis and scarring
  • Ankylosing glossitis

 

Management

  • Cessation of causative factors(tobacco, chilli, areca nut)
  • Oral hygiene
  • Dexamethasone local injections
  • Hydrocortisone
  • HCG submucosal injection
  • Vitamin and iron supplementation
  • Surgical excision with graft
  • Stem cell therapy

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presents with a swelling in the midline of his neck that shifts when he swallows or sticks out his tongue. What is the probable diagnosis?
A patient presents with swelling in the floor of the mouth. Upon examination, the swelling appears as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ranula

Definition

Ranulas are a type of extravasation mucocele caused by the rupture of the main duct or obstructed acini of the sublingual gland. They appear as bluish swellings on the floor of the mouth and resemble the belly of a frog.

Location
  • Commonly found in the anterior floor of the mouth.
  • When it extends through the mylohyoid muscle, it presents as a submental swelling known as a "plunging ranula."

Symptoms

Typically soft, fluctuant, and painless unless infected.

Diagnosis
  • Confirmed through Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)
  • Ultrasound
  • Aspiration of thick, sticky saliva differentiates it from a lymphangioma.

Treatment
  • Removal of the sublingual gland is preferred.
  • Incision, drainage, and marsupialisation have low success rates. Although marsupialisation is often adequate, it has a higher recurrence rate compared to sublingual gland excision.
  • OK-432 injection
  • Botulinum toxin injections

questions.explanation: Correct option C - Ranu

questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Trach

questions.text: An elderly male presents with foul-smelling breath and dysphagia. A barium swallow X-ray is provided. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Zenker's diverticulum

Clinical features:
  • Dysphagia is the most prominent feature appears when the pouch gets filled with food and presses on the oesophagus.
  • Gurgling sound is produced on swallowing.
  • Regurgitation at night from undigested food causes cough and aspiration pneumonia.
  • Halitosis (Chronic bad breathing)
  • Malnourished due to dysphagia.
  • Associated hiatus hernia
  • Rarely can a coma develop in long-standing cases of pharyngeal pouches.

Diagnosis:
  • Barium swallow provides information regarding the size, location, and character of the mucosal lining.

 

 

 
  • Endoscopy reveals fibrosis and pooling of food in the diverticulum.

Treatment:
  • Excision of the pouch and cricopharyngeal myotomy was done through a cervical approach.
  • Dohlman’s procedure: The partition wall between the oesophagus and the pouch is exposed and divided by diathermy through a weerda scope.
  • Endoscopic laser treatment: Partition wall between the oesophagus and the pouch is exposed and divided by CO2 laser using an endoscope. This procedure is known to have fewer recurrences and faster improvement in symptoms.

questions.text: Identify the level of lymph nodes indicated in the marked region of the neck in the given anatomical image.
questions.explanation:
Level

Anatomical Location

Key Features

Level I

Submental & submandibular

Divided into Ia (midline) & Ib (lateral)

Level II

Upper internal jugular nodes

Jugulodigastric region (common in nasopharyngeal CA)

Level III

Mid-jugular region

Between the hyoid & cricoid

Level IV

Lower jugular nodes

Between the cricoid & clavicle

Level V

Posterior triangle

Spinal accessory nodes

questions.explanation: Correct Option A - E

options.label: C
options.text: Superficial Biopsy from the Border with Normal Tissue

questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Incisional B

questions.text: A 65-year-old smoker presents with ulcerative lesions on his lower lip for the past year. On examination, there is a palpable ipsilateral submental lymph node approximately 5x5 cm. A biopsy from the lesion is suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. What is the next step in management?

options.label: D
options.text: Resection of primary lesion with lip reconstruction and MRND

questions.correct_answer: D. Resection of primary lesion with lip reconstruction and MRND
questions.explanation:
T Stage

  • Tis: Carcinoma in situ
  • T1: Tumor ≤2 cm and ≤5 mm depth of invasion
  • T2: Tumor ≤2 cm and >5 mm but ≤10 mm depth, OR
    Tumor >2 cm but ≤4 cm and ≤10 mm depth
  • T3: Tumor >4 cm OR any tumor >10 mm depth of invasion
  • T4: Invasion of adjacent structures

N Stage:

  • N0: No regional lymph node metastasis
  • N1-N3: Based on number, size, and laterality of involved nodes

M Stage:

  • M0: No distant metastasis
  • M1: Distant metastasis

Early Stage (T1-T2N0)
  • Wide local excision with 1 cm margins
  • Consider elective neck dissection for tumours>2 cm or >4 mm in depth
  • Reconstruction: Primary closure, local flaps, or skin grafts

Advanced Stage (T3-T4 or N+)
  • Wide local excision with ≥1 cm margins
  • Neck dissection (comprehensive or selective based on nodal status)
  • Complex reconstruction (local/regional flaps, free tissue transfer)
  • Adjuvant radiotherapy or chemoradiotherapy based on pathological findings

Reconstruction Options
  • Wedge excision and primary closure (for small lesions)
  • Local flaps: Abbe-Estlander, Karapandzic, nasolabial
  • Regional flaps: Forehead, cervicofacial
  • Free tissue transfer: Radial forearm free flap, anterolateral thigh flap

Management of the Neck
  • Elective neck dissection for high-risk tumours (>2 cm, >4 mm depth)
  • Therapeutic neck dissection for clinically positive nodes
  • Levels typically addressed: I-III for N0 neck, I-V for N+ neck

Radiotherapy
  • Adjuvant: For positive margins, perineural invasion, multiple positive nodes
  • Definitive: For patients unfit for surgery or refusing surgery
  • Brachytherapy: Can be considered for select early-stage lesions

Chemotherapy
  • Not routinely used in early-stage disease
  • It may be combined with radiotherapy in locally advanced cases

Follow-up and Surveillance

Regular follow-up visits: Every 1-3 months for the first year, then gradually decreasing frequency

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department following severe maxillofacial trauma sustained in a road traffic accident. The airway is compromised, and immediate intervention is required. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
In modified radical neck dissection, which of the following structures is NOT preserved?
questions.explanation:
Dissection

LN removed

Other structures removed/Preserved

Radical Neck Dissection

I - V

CN XI, IJV, and SCM removed

Modified Radical Neck Dissection (MRND) I

I - V

CN XI preserved

MRND II

I - V

CN XI, IJV preserved

MRND III

I - V

CN XI, IJV, SCM preserved

Extended Neck Dissection

I - V

CN XI, IJV, SCM removed + one/more LN groups +/- Non lymphatic structures

Selective Neck Dissections

LN removed

Primary site of cancer

Supra-omohyoid

I - III

Oral cavity

Extended Supra-omohyoid

 

I - IV

Oral cavity and oropharynx

Postero-Lateral

II - V

Skin over the posterior scalp and upper neck

Lateral

II - IV

Oropharynx, Hypopharynx, Larynx

Anterior/ Central

VI

Thyroid/ Midline structures

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a young patient under 5 years of age presenting with a painless, soft, fluctuating mass on the lateral side of the neck?
What is the condition depicted in the given image, and what is the next investigation required for management?
questions.explanation:
Leukoplakia

Oral candidiasis

  • Premalignant lesion
  • Causes: Pan masala chewing, Tobacco chewing, Betel quid
  • Can be seen in adults above 40 years.
  • White patch or plaque
  • Surgical excision, CO2 laser, and medications can be used to treat.
  • Premalignant lesion
  • Caused by Candida albicans
  • Seen in immunosuppressed
  • White curdy lesions
  • Treated by topical antifungals, surgery, or lasers.
